docs.lead_paragraph: Many pregnant women may undergo unnecessary Caesarean sections, a new study suggests, because they have ''white-coat hypertension,'' which is high blood pressure that happens only when they are around doctors.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Pseudo-Hypertension Causes Needless Surgery

docs.abstract: Study finds 42 of 144 pregnant women studied suffered blood pressure that was high only when they were around doctors; study, published in Journal of American Medical Association, suggests many pregnant women may undergo unnecessary Caesarean sections because drugs used to treat their false hypertension can prevent normal contractions (S)
docs.snippet: Many pregnant women may undergo unnecessary Caesarean sections, a new study suggests, because they have ''white-coat hypertension,'' which is high blood pressure that happens only when they are around doctors.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: The association representing the state's acute-care hospitals has filed suit saying that a new law requiring H.I.V. testing for newborns or their mothers violates the United States and Connecticut constitutions. The Connecticut Hospital Association went to Federal District Court seeking to overturn the law, which took effect Oct. 1. The new law requires either the mother or her infant to be tested for the virus that causes AIDS. If the mother refuses the test, the newborn must be tested.

headline.main: H.I.V. Tests for Mothers Or Newborns Challenged

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Fighting Trend, Women Choose to Bear With Pain'' (news article, Oct. 18): By calling no-drug childbirths ''a remarkable rite of passage'' for women, Catherine M. Clark, a midwife, implies that women are somehow incomplete unless they bear children.

docs.lead_paragraph: Once again a woman's right to choose abortion is under direct attack in Congress. The Senate is poised to vote today on the latest Congressional attempt to impose a national ban on so-called partial birth abortions. Billed by its proponents as a narrow targeting of a single late-term procedure, the measure is actually a backdoor attempt to severely constrict abortion rights throughout all stages of pregnancy. This reality has not been lost on the courts. Since the Senate's last partial birth vote, there have been 11 court decisions on the legal merits of partial birth bans passed by different states. In all but one instance, the ban was blocked because of constitutional problems.
docs.abstract: Editorial comments on fresh attack by Republican Congressional lawmakers against abortion accuses them of spreading deceptions about partial birth abortions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the debate over the use of regional anesthesia in childbirth misidentified a couple shown in a class at the Elizabeth Seton Childbirthing Center in Greenwich Village. They were Suchita and Dhiraj Nayar -- not Guillermina Ramirez and Saul Flores, who also attended a class there.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though much has been said and thought about the female breast, there remains one aspect that has received little consideration: the actual number that a woman has, with two accepted as the immutable standard. In fact, humans, like other mammals, can vary in their numbers of nipples and more rarely breasts, raising this little-pondered question: Why do humans, or for that matter any mammals, have the number of mammaries that they do?

headline.main: Of Breasts, Behavior and the Size of Litters

docs.abstract: Question of why humans, and other mammals, have the number of breasts they do discussed; new study on naked mole rats, curious breed of mammal that tends to have 11 breasts, suggests that reason they have what seem to be so many extra mammaries may be to keep sharing and fighting to a minimum in largest litters; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Though much has been said and thought about the female breast, there remains one aspect that has received little consideration: the actual number that a woman has, with two accepted as the immutable standard.    In fact, humans, like other mammals,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, as a long morning of labor dragged into afternoon, Elba M. Quinones soaked in a warm tub at an outpatient birthing center in Greenwich Village, trying to ease her pain. Her contractions came every three minutes. And when they intensified, her screams at times became primal. Once she howled to her husband that she couldn't take it any more. An hour and a half later, after leaving the warm water, pacing, squatting and reclining on the room's two-poster queen bed, Ms. Quinones gave birth to Omar Rafael, her first child. She promptly announced that she had made the right decision: to experience childbirth naturally, without drugs -- extreme pain and all.

headline.main: Bearing With the Pain, and Fighting a Trend; Devotees of No-Drug Childbirth Frustrated by Rise in Use of Anesthesia

docs.abstract: Midwives and natural-birth advocates express frustration that drug-free childbirth is now being widely shunned; cite study by Dr Joy L Hawkins showing that number of women in labor who received regional anesthesia soared from 1981 to 1997; midwives say number of pregnant women who are seeking them out has also climbed, though rise is not as sharp; midwifery is especially well established in New York State, where 10.8 percent of deliveries in 1997 were attended by certified nurse-midwives (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The issue is not whether a woman should have pain medication during labor and childbirth (front page, Oct. 13). The issue is whether she understands all the options, risks and benefits before labor. There is no standard answer to pain for each woman because each labor experience is unique. The pain and pressure she feels depends on her health, her emotional state, her attitudes toward the birth process, how much sleep she has had, the position of the baby, her own position and more.
docs.abstract: Cathleen Phelps letter, commenting on October 13 article, says issue is not whether woman should have pain medication during labor and childbirth; says issue is whether she understands all options, risks and benefits before labor (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOME addiction counselors classify the children of alcoholics into behavioral types: the hero child, who tries to save the family by doing everything right; the scapegoat, who constantly fails and gets into trouble, and the lost child, who goes AWOL from the family dynamic and develops a private solution, sometimes with disastrous results. With the ironically titled ''Joe the King,'' which opened on Friday, Frank Whaley has made an intensely affecting yet unsentimental movie about a lost child. That the film contains a large dollop of autobiography -- it is dedicated to his parents -- only makes this 36-year-old actor's achievement more striking.

headline.main: Picturing a Lost Boy, Drawing on Memory
